Along with a reputation as one of the world's greatest bio-physicists Dr Detlev Wulf Bronk, sixth president of the Hopkins, brings to
Homewood a warm congeniality for his associates and a fresh enthusiasm for his work.
The new president of the University has a deep feeling for the
undergraduites and a strong concern for their relationship to the
University at large.

opportunity for undergraduates,

Carlyle Barton Praises
New Hopkins President
Editor, The News-Letter:
As President of the Board of Trustees, I am pleased to join
the
News - Letter in extending a welcome to Detlev W Bronk, the
new
President of The Johns Hopkins University ...
Johns Hopkins is assured of a continuation of the same kind of
wise and vigorous leadership that has characterized Dr Bowman's
administration during thirteen and a half years. Dr Bronk's eminence
as a scientist, h-is background- and interest in student problems,
and
his experience as an administrator, provide a guarantee that every
element —
within the university will be strengthened by his presence.
CARLYLE BARTON
President of the Board of Trustees

Scabbard & Blade
Initiates Ten Cadets
Company I, 2nd Regiment of the
National Society of Scabbard and
Blade initiated ten men into its
ranks on Thursday night, January 13.
The society is an honorary
ROTC fraternity which has been
on the Hopkins campus since
1920. It was inactive during the
war and this is the second such
Initiation since the society was
reactivated last year. It is open
to Cadet officers in the ROTC
whose work and interest in the
military has made them outstanding in the eyes of the PMST and
the members of the society.
The men that were initiated
were: from the Infantry: Robert
C Hall, Wilbur K ITammaker,
Ross G Macaulay, Malcomb D
Mahr, Marvin M Spector, James A
ISyphard; from the Air group:
Kenneth D Hudson, Frederick C
Lang; and from the Engineers:
Vernon K Garritt, Jr, and William
0 Dulling.
There was a party after the initiation in honor of the new members. Many of the officers of the
ROTC Department as well as all
the members of the society were
present.

Through chemistry,farmers are gaining control over many of nature's uncertainties. Costly losses ofcrops and
livestock are being curtailed or prevented. Efficiency is increasing. New
applications of chemistry to agriculture are becoming more important
than ever as demands for more production increase.
Today, new organic insecticides
and fungicides help control insects,
plantdiseases and blightsthat threaten crops. Seed disinfectants and protectants help guarantee bountiful
harvests by protecting crops in the
critical period after planting. Plant
hormones hold fruit on trees until
fully ready for picking.
Days of labor saved
Du Pont weed killers and explosives
accomplish in minutes tasks that
used to take hours or days of backbreaking labor. With 2,4-D farmers
can kill weeds without harming certain crops. Dynamite removes
stumps,digs ditches for draining and
irrigation, and loosens the soil to
forestall erosion.
New fertilizer formulations meet
the changing nutritional requirements of plants during the growing
season. Thus the farmer has better
control over crop development, and
he can utilize his materials,labor and

Achievements such as these are the
result of Du Pont's team research.
An idea may start with one or two
individuals. But many specialists—
chemists,physicists, biologists, plant
pathologists, and entomologists —
must contribute their skills before a
new product is ready for market.
Normally, engineers—chemical, mechanical, civil, and electrical — develop the commercial processes and
plants for making the finished products.
The new Du Pont employee,
whether he holds a bachelor's, master's, or doctor's degree, enters into
this cooperative effort. Yet the immediate group with which he is associated is small and congenial,offering
him every opportunity to display
individual talent and capabilities.

Athletics Called Essential
Dr Bronk also regards athletics
as an essential part of education.
However, he explained that he does
not think that the purpose of educational institutions is to provide
"mass entertainment." "If the purpose of varsity athletics is to raise
money for institutions," the president added with a smile, why not
hire professional teams, rather
than a handful of student athletes."
"Every student should be offered an opportunity to play some school."

Inside Story of Invasion of, Russia
Exposes Contemporary Hitler Myth

"4r

By RICHARD W SONNENFELDT

Mr Richard Sonnenfeldt, chief interpreter of the United 'States prosecution at the Nurenberg
War Crime Trials, presents this week the second in a series of articles exposing the myth that has
characterized our failure to understand the men inside Germany in World War II. The nature of Mr.
Sonnenfeldt's work has brought him in intimate contact with the group of Nazi leaders whose statements are the source material for this exclusive series of articles.

are the objects of a college education?

Dr Detlev Bronk, the new president of the Hopkins, commenting on this subject in a News-Letter interview, explained that regardless of the vocational activity of an individual, life can be
much more satisfying for a person if he has "the intellectual
resources to realize and discover the things which make life interestin." As Dr Bronk views the problem, this is a fundamental object
of college education.
Dr Bronk reminds us that"every day we become more aware of
the increasing complexity of our world." The Hopkins president
explains "an understanding of economio and political pressures
in this world will enable us to better find our place as individuals."
The academic and professional training that colleges and universities offer are of advantage to many but not to all of the students
engaging in preparation for future-vocational activity. The broad
values of education, however, which contribute to the enrichment
of the "intellectual resources" of all students is the more encompassing objective of education. At a time when the values of the
American college and university systems are the subject of critical
scrutiny, the Hopkins has at the head of its administration not
only a scientist who enhances the academic prestige of the University but an educator aware of the Hopkins relation to the
objectives of enduring value to the undergraduates.

FRATERNITIES PLAY POP
Two of the Hopkins fraternities played Santa Claus before
the Christmas holiday for a group of local orphans. The members
of the campus social groups entertained the youngsters with a
Christmas dinner and then presented them with presents. After
the partying the boys retired to the floor with their guests and
entertained them just like "pop."
As the fraternities extend their interest beyond the concern
for exclusive rushing and big parties they provide a strong argument for the exponents of the campus groups. If the fraternity
system is to survive it will be the positive and not the negative acts
which determine its endurance. The Hopkins fraternities that
played Santa Claus have established a worthy precedent.

onto a hardwood surface. We even check their feet to be

Scabbard & Blade
Initiates Ten Cadets
Company I, 2nd Regiment of the
National Society of Scabbard and
Blade initiated ten men into its
ranks on Thursday night, January 13.
The society is an honorary
ROTC fraternity which has been
on the Hopkins campus since
1920. It was inactive during the
war and this is the second such
Initiation since the society was
reactivated last year. It is open
to Cadet officers in the ROTC
whose work and interest in the
military has made them outstanding in the eyes of the PMST and
the members of the society.
The men that were initiated
were: from the Infantry: Robert
C Hall, Wilbur K ITammaker,
Ross G Macaulay, Malcomb D
Mahr, Marvin M Spector, James A
ISyphard; from the Air group:
Kenneth D Hudson, Frederick C
Lang; and from the Engineers:
Vernon K Garritt, Jr, and William
0 Dulling.
There was a party after the initiation in honor of the new members. Many of the officers of the
ROTC Department as well as all
the members of the society were
present.

Dr Detlev Bronk, the new president of the Hopkins, commenting on this subject in a News-Letter interview, explained that regardless of the vocational activity of an individual, life can be
much more satisfying for a person if he has "the intellectual

The academic and professional training that colleges and universities offer are of advantage to many but not to all of the students
engaging in preparation for future-vocational activity. The broad
values of education, however, which contribute to the enrichment
of the "intellectual resources" of all students is the more encompassing objective of education. At a time when the values of the
American college and university systems are the subject of critical
scrutiny, the Hopkins has at the head of its administration not
only a scientist who enhances the academic prestige of the University but an educator aware of the Hopkins relation to the
objectives of enduring value to the undergraduates.

FRATERNITIES PLAY POP
Two of the Hopkins fraternities played Santa Claus before
the Christmas holiday for a group of local orphans. The members
of the campus social groups entertained the youngsters with a
Christmas dinner and then presented them with presents. After
the partying the boys retired to the floor with their guests and
entertained them just like "pop."
As the fraternities extend their interest beyond the concern
for exclusive rushing and big parties they provide a strong argument for the exponents of the campus groups. If the fraternity
system is to survive it will be the positive and not the negative acts
which determine its endurance. The Hopkins fraternities that
played Santa Claus have established a worthy precedent.
